title: Open Data in a Day
body: This introductory course aims to get you up to speed with latest developments in open data and its significance. It is designed to enable anyone to get started with discovering and using open data and understand the skills and processes required to make it work for you and your organisation.

title: Course overview
body: The course is split into four main sessions. These sessions start by exploring definitions of open data, examines the impacts and future directions of the field, looks at practical aspects such as licencing and best practices and concludes with a hands-on exploration of some key tools.

_items.title: Introducing Open Data
_items.body:
The session explores recent changes in the definition of open data, and allow learners to understand why the current definition has been determined.

The session also examines a number of examples of open data impact from different fields and considers the potential for open data implementation

_items.alt: Challenges of Open Data and Future Developments
_items.title: Unlocking data from the web
_items.body: Open data is still a developing field and those working within it will encounter a number of common problems. This sessions presents and clarifys the main challenges before examining the future of open data.

_items.title: Licensing and Best Practices
_items.body:
This session begins by looking at how open licences are there to protect data publishers, while also unlocking value. We show how to build a machine readable open license that can be applied to any online content.

The session then continues by looking at the technical, legal, social and practical requirements for making different types of open data usable and some of the most relevant guidelines to support this process.

_items.title: Cleaning Open Data
_items.body: This session will introduce the importance of recent changes around open data modification rules which help combat data errors. We also introduce OpenRefine and how it improves data management by publishers.

title: The benefits of Open Data
body: This session explores the definition of open data and examines some examples of the benefits of open data. Below to support this discussion you can explore some of the main benefits of open data together with examples.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Support growing economies
_items.body:
To support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones, governments need to publish key datasets.

Governments also need to support data infrastructures that connect data with those who use it.

In return, governments are reaping the benefits of a growing data economy as in Finland, where SMEs with access to open data grew 15% faster than those without.

Take me to Finnish case study

_items.title: Improved service delivery
_items.body:
Governments need to balance the demands of growing populations with the need to tackle small-scale, local issues.

The availability of detailed open data is essential to improve delivery of services at the local level.

Some of these new services are available now -
Take me to mySociety
Take me to the Hungarian 'right to know' portal
Take me to Fix my Street Norway

_items.title: Cost savings
_items.body:
By growing economies and improving services, open data allows governments to make savings in key areas, like provision of healthcare, education and utilities.

In the UK, open data helped reveal £200 million of savings in the health service

In France, energy data is being used to drive more efficient energy generation practices
Show me the France energy data.

Open data can also bring transparency to budgets. In Switzerland, the canton of Bern presented their €400m annual saving to the public using open data

title: Challenges of Open Data and Future Developments
displayTitle: Challenges of Open Data and Future Developments

title: Challenges of Open Data
body: Open data is still a developing field and faces a number of key challenges which need to be addressed. The following section outlines some of the key areas
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock data that is on the web.

_items.title: Inconsistent definitions
_items.body:
Like any new field, open data needs a strong definition to give clarity around what it is and what you can do with it. While many definitions of open data currently exist, promoted by different organisations and meeting different needs, there is no consistency about the terms used in these definitions.

A recent study by GovLab has highlighted the number of different terms used when defining open data in a simple chart that illustrates the need for greater consistency.

_items.title: Lack of proper licences
_items.body:
Many search engines, including google, give you the ability to use advanced searches and prefixs in order to dig out data.

Try some of the following search prefixes in google to see what you can find:

filetype:

Search for specific file types only, e.g. (xls) (example)

site:

Search with a specific domain or site only (example)

related:

Search for content related to a known page (example)

link:

List only pages that link to the one given (example)

_items.title: Aggregators and portals
_items.body:
Aggregates and portals bring together data from accross the web and expose through their own service. This creates and easy and consistant way to find and download data.

Explore the links below to find out more:

enigma.io

Powerful open data searching for structured data

Transport API

All UK transport data, in one place, with one API.

_items.title: Web scraping
_items.body:
If you can't simply download data in a usable format, you may need to scrape it. Helpfully there are now many tools that help us achieve this easily:

pdftables.com

Upload a PDF, download data, simple.

magic.import.io

Extract data from web pages in a click.

title: Unlocking data in the web
body: A lot of data is not available via seraches or download buttons. To unlock this data we have to think more like a computer.
instruction: Click below to explore each of the tools to unlock data from in the web.

_items.title: Adding extensions
_items.body:
Some web pages are also data resources in themselves. In these cases you can try adding data file extensions (e.g. csv, json, xml, rdf etc) to the web address in order to access structured data.

Try some of the examples below to see what you find:

All gov.uk data

Add '.json' to any page of gov.uk (e.g. the UK Trade Tariff data).

BBC Programme pages

Add '.xml' or '.rdf' to any BBC programme page (e.g. Doctor Who).

_items.title: Finding alternative links
_items.body:
Some websites offer data feeds in the form of RSS feeds or email subscriptions. Such services provide timely updates of new information and can be reused by many applications.

The following a good examples of data feeds that are available:

  • BBC News Feeds
  • Met Office Weather feeds

_items.title: Extracting embedded data
_items.body:
Many websites dynamically load data, saving web browsers time loading endless pages. This is especially the case with embedde weather widgets and sholling websites where templates are filled with data once they are loaded.

As a nice aside, this means that your web browser has loaded structured data onto your computer. All we have to do is access it directly so it can be used.

Try out the hidden data extractor and see what you can find hiding in existing web pages.

_items.title: Content negotiation
_items.body:
Content negotiation is the machine equivalent of adding file extensions to ask for different formats.

Rather than add extensions, machines can provide a list of priorities for formats they would like and negotiate with the server to get these.

You can find out more about content negotiation from Wikipedia.

_items.title: Using APIs
_items.body:
Application Programme Interfaces (APIs) are machine interfaces designed for specific serviecs.

They are most often designed to allow applications to query data and in some cases make changes to the data.

In many cases an API is simply a pattern of web addresses (URLs) that can be adjusted to perform different actions.

Examples of APIs in action include:

  • Flickr
  • OpenCorporates
  • Transport API

title: Data structures and formats
body:
The format of a dataset is the way in which the data is structured and made available for humans and machines.

Choosing the right format enables simpler management and reuse of the data. To maximise reuse of the data, it may be necessary to translate your data into a number of formats and structures.

Explore the different structures and formats with this exercise.

title: Machine learning and classification
body:
Machine learning is all about the construction and study of systems that can learn from data.

There are many techniques that can be used with data, however one of the most common techniques is classification.

When classifing data, you first train the machine with a training set, and then test effectivness are error margin with a test set. This can then lead to automated ways of classifying new data.

Classification techniuqes are commonly used with facial recognition, email spam filters and fraud detection.

In this section we are going to look at classifying a dataset of houses.

Download the houses dataset

title: Exploring R
body:
R is statistic programming language. It can rapidly speed up the process of freely and flexibly exploring and discovering insight from a dataset.

Additional libraries also provide automatied mechanisms for building machine learning algorithms and classifiers.

This exercise takes you through the process of exploring R with our dataset

Open R Studio Online to get started with this exercise (requires registration).

title: Exploring data through visualisation
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Exploring space
_items.body:
The Universe is vast and on a scale people just simply cannot grasp.

Visualising this effectively is key to increase understanding of our place in the Universe.

_items.title: Faster transport?
_items.body:
Visualising data can quickly tell us stories of progress.

The example on the left became part of the advertising campaigne for SNCF. It was used to communicate how much fater the new TGV trains were.

_items.title: Light cycles
_items.body:
Improving mobility is key to the future of successful and smart cities.

Visualising usage of transport systems (in this case bicycles in London) can help make key decisions about future planning of such systems.

Click here to watch the full video.

_items.title: In flight
_items.body:
Transport problems are not just limited to single cities. There is a lot we can learn from analysing global transport patterns.

This example looks at the evolution of flight and uses advanced visualision to tell a story about the history of flight. Using a bit of machine learning, it even attempts to predict the future.

Click here to explore In Flight

title: Exploring complex datasets
body:
Visualisations can help us explore a dataset to unlock insight.

In particular facetted browsing (or cross filters) allow consumers to filter the data visually. Such browsers are commonly now used by holiday and flight websites, such as Sky scanner to help you filter your search results or change input parameters.

Try out this exercise to build your own cross filter with the housing data from earlier

You will need this link to start the exercise.

title: Open Data Science
body:
Data science combines advanced data literacy and statistical knowledge with domain expertise. This combination of skills helps derive valuable insights and communicate them to others.

In this course we explored some of the key specialisms of a data scientist, in particular 'data skills', 'machine learning' and 'visualisation'.

The houses dataset provided a solid base for demonstrate and I must thank those behind r2d3.us for putting this excellent data science demo together.

Looking to the future, more data will increase the need to be able to filter it. Perhaps one day we shall all be using tools like Pivot.
